For the epoxidation of methyl oleate (MO), slow chemical reaction rate resulted from poor mass transfer remains a tough problem. Herein, we demonstrate a series of efficient 2D channel catalysts with accessible open transport channels, which provides an idea strategy for boosting epoxidation of MO and shortening its reaction time. 2D channel catalysts (2D-CSx-NH2-HPA) are fabricated by immobilizing heteropoly acid (HPA) on aminopropyl-functionalized 2D channel silica (2D-CSx-NH2), in which HPA is highly dispersed. These catalysts are applied to the epoxidation of MO, and the results show that the epoxidation performance of 2D channel catalysts for MO is related to its particle size and HPA types. As expected, the 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW with a length of 300 nm and an equatorial diameter of 150 nm exhibits outstanding catalytic activity (XMO = 91.68%) and epoxide selectivity (SEMO = 90.03%) with only 4 hours, which is much faster than that of majority of epoxidation catalysts reported so far. The excellent catalytic activity of 2D channel catalyst benefits from the appropriate pore width and particle size, which play an important role in exchanging substrates and dispersing active components. This study uses 2D channel catalyst to effectively shorten the reaction time of MO epoxidation, which paves a new avenue to develop other 2D channel materials for novel catalytic applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract 2D channel catalyst was designed to promote the epoxidation of methyl oleate due to its accessible open transport channels that facilitate molecular diffusion. Keywords 2D channel catalyst Accessible open transport channels Methyl oleate, Epoxidation Catalytic activity Epoxide selectivity Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction The depletion of fossil resources and environmental problems have led to urgent research concerns on the utilization of biomass [1–3]. Among them, vegetable oils and their fatty acid methyl esters are readily available, renewable and environment-friendly natural resources that can replace fossil resources in the manufacture of chemical products. Considering the huge market demand for products synthesized by the epoxidation of methyl oleate (MO), such as plasticizers [4,5], lubricants [6,7], coating stabilizer [8], biofuel additives [9], the development of catalysts to help achieve the epoxidation of MO has become very relevant. As of now several types of heterogeneous catalysts have been reported as effective catalysts for epoxidation reaction such as metal oxides [10,11], enzyme [12], and HPA [13], etc. Among them, HPA has the advantages of easy dispersion and superacid properties [14], which seems to be the most promising catalyst for the epoxidation of MO. It has been reported early that peroxo phosphotungstate {PO4[WO(O2)2]4}3− is an efficient catalyst for the epoxidation of oleic acid, yielding 84% of the epoxide [15]. However, low surface area of bulk HPA hinders their performance as a heterogeneous catalyst and the solubility of HPA makes recovery difficult [16]. Therefore, the HPA as an active components need to be immobilized on the carrier to solve above problems. It was reported that heterogeneous catalysts for soybean oil epoxidation were prepared by loading {PO4[W(O)(O2)2]4}3− on modified halloysite nanotubes, and the conversion of soybean oil was found to increase with increasing reaction time, indicating that the prepared catalysts could effectively catalyze soybean oil epoxidation [17]. In order to sufficiently utilize the active components, PPT-SBA-15 catalyst was successfully prepared using a silylating agent to trap peroxyphosphotungstate in SBA-15, which is promising for the synthesis of epoxides of long-chain carbon [18]. The resin-supported peroxyphosphotungstic acid catalyst also showed excellent catalytic performance for the epoxidation of dicyclopentadiene, obtaining high dicyclopentadiene conversion and monocyclic oxide selectivity [19]. In addition, novel heteropolyacid-based hybrid composites were obtained by immobilizing phosphomolybdic acid (HPMo) on a covalent organic backbone material, and the composites can be used as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the epoxidation of cyclooctene [20]. However, MO has a long epoxidation time and low efficiency due to its poor mass transfer in the channel of catalysts. Therefore, there is an exigency to explore a suitable catalyst carrier that can reduce epoxidation time of MO. 2D channel materials as an ideal carrier have accessible open transport channels which help to achieve fast mass transfer and efficient utilization of active sites [21–23]. With the findings of 2D graphene [24,25], systematic studies of many other 2D materials have increased rapidly, including hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) [26,27], graphitic carbon-nitride (g-C3N4) [28,29], layered double hydroxides (LDHs) [30,31], MXene [32,33], layered silica [21,34], etc. The unique structural and electronic properties of 2D materials have led to a wide range of applications in some significant research fields, including ion transport, optoelectronic devices, catalysis, biomedicine, energy storage [35,36]. Based on these, we believe that the prepared 2D channel silica (2D-CSx) is a viable class of catalytic carriers since it can be easily modified and has sufficient channels, high specific surface area, superior stability and biocompatibility. As the reactants pass through the open channels, the reactants can effectively collide with the active components and thus undergo epoxidation reactions [37]. There are few reports on 2D channel materials due to their difficulty in forming effective interlayer spaces. In contrast, layered silica can form open channels that can easily transport substances because it can form wrinkled stacks. To the best of our knowledge, few reports are published on the use of 2D channel mesoporous silica-based catalysts for accelerated oil-water biphasic catalysis. In this work, we reported the synthesis of 2D channel catalyst and its first application in the epoxidation of MO. A series of 2D-CSx with different morphologies and particles size were prepared by varying the amount of aqueous ammonia. Furthermore, by comparing the catalytic performance of HPA, phosphotungstic acid (HPW) is more suitable than HPMO as the active component for this catalytic reaction. Surprisingly, 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW exhibited significant catalytic performance under condensation reflux conditions with only 4 hours. It is noteworthy that the obtained epoxy compounds are stable in this reaction system, while side reactions such as epoxy ring opening may occur more easily in conventional homogeneous acidic systems. To confirm these findings, the effects of synthesis conditions on catalyst and reaction conditions on conversion and selectivity of epoxidation were investigated. 2D channel catalyst can be recycled five times under the same conditions with no significant degradation in catalytic performance. Finally, the mechanism of using 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst to realize rapid and efficient epoxidation of MO is clarified. This study effectively shortens the reaction time of MO epoxidation and paves a new avenue to develop other 2D channel materials for novel catalytic applications. Experiment Materials Phosphotungstic acid (HPW), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), Phosphomolybdic acid (HPMo), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), n-octane, hydrogen peroxide solution (H2O2, 30 wt%), and acetonitrile were obtained from Kermel. Methyl oleate (MO, 99 wt%) was provided by Macklin, China. 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) was supplied by Aladdin, China. Aqueous ammonia (25 wt%), anhydrous ethanol and ethyl acetate (EA) were purchased from Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co. The purchased reagents are used directly without any additional purification. Synthesis of 2D-CSx The 2D-CSx was similarly prepared via the liquid template corrosion (LTC) method published in our previous work [34]. Following the usual steps, 1.36 g of CTAB was added to the reactor at room temperature, followed by 80 mL of deionized water to dissolve it and stirred quickly for 10 min to get a uniform and clear solution. Then, x mL of aqueous ammonia was added dropwise to the above solution (x = 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4) and 20 mL of EA was added slowly in drops after 15 min. After completing this step, 7.2 mL of TEOS was dripped at a constant rate to the mixture. Subsequently, pour the mixture into a Teflon reactor and heat it at 100°C for 1 day. The obtained sample was filtered and washed several times alternately with anhydrous ethanol and distilled water, and finally dried at 80°C overnight. To remove CTAB, the material was dispersed in 100 mL of HCl/ethanol solution (2.4 * 10−2 mM) and refluxed at 80°C for 5 hours. After completing the above steps, the material was filtered, washed repeatedly with distilled water, and finally dried at 100°C for 6 hours. The prepared sample was expressed as 2D-CSx (x = 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4). Synthesis of amino-modified 2D-CSx The 2D-CSx was functionalized by grafting organosilane onto layered silica. Within a typical approach, 100 mL of toluene was added slowly to a reactor containing 1 g of 2D-CSx and ultrasonicated for 10 min to make 2D-CSx uniformly dispersed, followed by the addition of 0.35 mL of APTES. Subsequently, the above mixture was stirred and refluxed for 12 hours at 110°C under a N2 atmosphere. Then, the material was filtered, washed repeatedly with anhydrous ethanol, and finally dried at 100°C. The prepared amino-functionalized sample was designated as 2D-CSx-NH2. Synthesis of 2D-CSx-NH2-HPA and MCM-41-NH2-HPW Anchoring the HPA molecules on 2D-CSx-NH2 was accomplished by the following method. The first step was to place 1 g of 2D-CSx-NH2 in a reactor and then add 100 mL of anhydrous ethanol to make it uniformly dispersed. Then, the pre-configured HPA anhydrous ethanol solution was added dropwise to the above mixture and refluxed at 80°C for 5 h. After completing this step, the product was filtered, dried at 80°C for 6 h and coded as 2D-CSx-NH2-HPA. Synthesis of MCM-41-NH2-HPW: The synthesis process of MCM-41- NH2-HPW catalyst was similar to that of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW, except that the support was changed from 2D-CS3.5 to MCM-41 provided by Tianjin Yuanli Company. Materials characterization The phase structure of the prepared samples was measured by powder X-ray diffraction, using a D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker) with Cu Kα radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using a HITACHI SU-8010 electron microscopy. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of samples were texted using a FEI Tecnai F20. A Nicolet iS50 FT-IR Spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific) was used to analyze the infrared spectra of the samples. The weight loss of the samples was analyzed by STA449C (NETZSCH, Germany). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the samples was performed on an ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained by ASAP 2010 analyzer. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the material were analyzed using BET and BJH methods. Catalytic tests A 50 mL single-necked flask was used as a reaction device, which equipped with a condensing reflux system, to carry out the MO epoxidation reaction under heated condition. Specifically, 0.1 g of 2D-CSx-NH2-HPA catalyst and 0.6 g of MO were added to the device, following which 1.5 mL of acetonitrile was added as solvent. Finally, 0.68 g of hydrogen peroxide was dropped into the mixture, which was refluxed at 90°C for 4 hours. The product was finally obtained by separating the catalyst by centrifugation and removing the hydrogen peroxide and solvent by reduced pressure distillation on a rotary evaporator equipped with an explosion preventer. Epoxy methyl oleate (EMO) was detected by gas chromatography (Agilent 7890 GC) equipped with a flame ion detector (FID) and an HP-5 ms capillary column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.50 μm) to calculate the conversion of MO and the selectivity of the epoxidation product. The specific calculations [38] of MO conversion (XMO) and selectivity (SEMO) of EMO are as follows: X MO ( % ) = n MO 0 − n MO n MO 0 × 100 % S EMO ( % ) = n EMO n MO 0 − n MO × 100 % ∑ i = 1 n x i 2 The initial molar content of MO is represented by n MO 0 and the final molar content is represented by n MO . The molar content of EMO is denoted as n EMO . Results and discussion Characterization of 2D-CSx materials and 2D channel catalysts The morphology and structure of 2D-CSx samples were obtained by SEM characterization, as shown in Fig. 1 . As shown in Fig. 1A, the 2D-CS2.5 particles prepared at aqueous ammonia usage of 2.5 mL had a distinct spherical morphology with an average particle size of 150 nm. Continuing to increase the aqueous ammonia usage to 3 mL, the average particle size of the prepared 2D-CS3 sample was 200 nm and the prepared samples gradually changed from spherical to laminar ellipsoidal shape (Fig. 1B). The 2D-CS3.5 sample was prepared by adding 3.5 mL of aqueous ammonia to prepare, as shown in Fig. 1C. All particles have long ellipsoidal shape with length (L) of 300 nm and equatorial diameter (D) of 150 nm, and have obvious interlayer channels. When the amount of aqueous ammonia continued to be increased to 4 mL, the length of 2D-CS4 increased and the pore channels started to become significantly larger (Fig. 1D). The morphological structure of the prepared 2D-CSx is significantly different from that of MCM-41 which does not possess an axially stacked layer structure (Fig. S1). The result indicates that 2D channel silica materials with different morphologies and pore structures can be successfully prepared by varying the volume of aqueous ammonia. Specifically, the structure and morphology of 2D-CS3.5 sample and the derived catalysts were observed by SEM and HRTEM analysis, and these results are displayed in Fig. 2 . It is shown in Fig. 2A that particles have an elliptical shape with a length (L) of 300 nm and an equatorial diameter (D) of 150 nm. In addition, by comparing the light and dark streaks of nanoparticles, it was found that these nanoparticles are composed of layered silica with axially stacked lamellar structures and large interlayer space. At the same time, 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW was identified by SEM and TEM analysis (Fig. 2B and C). By comparing Fig. 2A and C, it can be found that 2D-CS3.5 still maintains its original morphological characteristics after the introduction of HPW. As seen from the HRTEM image (Fig. 2D, substance in the yellow circle is HPW), HPW particles were uniformly distributed on the 2D-CS3.5 carrier, and HPW particles were small without obvious agglomeration. This result reflects that the carrier after amino-functionalization promoted the HPW highly dispersed, which created a good condition for the 2D channel catalyst to boost the epoxidation of MO. Furthermore, elemental mapping analysis was used to identify the composition of the 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst (Fig. 2E). The characterization revealed that the catalyst consisted of N, Si, O, P and W elements and HPW was uniformly distributed, signifying that immobilization of -NH2 and HPW on 2D-CS3.5 was achieved successfully. Based on ICP analysis (Table S1), the actual HPW loading (24.73 wt %) of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW nano-composite catalysts was consistent with the theoretical loading (25 wt %), indicating the successful immobilization of the HPW on the surface of 2D-CS3.5. The porous structure of 2D-CS3.5 material and 2D channel catalysts were measured by N2 adsorption desorption method (Fig. 3 A and B). As shown in Fig. 3A, the results revealed that 2D-CS3.5 and its derived catalysts showed type IV isothermal with H3-type hysteresis loops [34,39]. The typical H3 hysteresis loop is a parallel plate structure with fissured pores. Moreover, the BET surface area of 2D-CS3.5-NH2 (233.85 m²/g) and 2D-CS3.5- NH2-HPW (130.85 m2/g) are also lower than that of 2D-CS3.5 (556.49 m2/g), shows that HPW and -NH2 were successfully immobilized and grafted on 2D-CS3.5. These finds show that 2D channel catalyst has a layered structure, which is in agreement with the SEM and TEM analysis. This detailed specific surface area information of the prepared materials is shown in Table 1 . It is shown in Fig. 3B that the pore size distribution of both 2D-CS3.5-NH2 and 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW ended up lower than that of 2D-CS3.5, indicating that -NH2 and HPW were successfully grafted and immobilized on 2D-CS3.5. The crystalline phase of prepared 2D-CS3.5 material and its derivative catalysts was measured by XRD spectra (Fig. 3C and Fig. S2). These results displayed a broad and intense peak at 2θ=23.5° for both the 2D channel silica material and its derived catalysts, which is characteristic of amorphous silica. Additionally, no characteristic peaks of HPW appeared in the XRD spectra of prepared catalysts, which confirmed that the HPW particles were uniformly dispersed on the silica carrier [40]. The presence of -NH2 groups and HPW on the samples was confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), as illustrated in Fig. 3D and Fig. S3. These peaks at 798.91, 1094.22, 1265.06 and 3443.92 cm−1 in the FT-IR spectra of 2D-CS3.5, 2D-CS3.5-NH2 and 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW belong to the tensile vibration peaks of Si-O-Si [40–42]. Keggin structure peaks were discovered in the FT-IR spectra of pure HPW at 1077.86 (P-O band), 980.13 (W=O band), 889.35 (W-Ob-W band) and 795.96 cm−1 (W-Oc-W band). In comparison with pure silica, the peaks of 1502.84 and 2927.45 cm−1 for 2D-CS3.5-NH2 and 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW correspond to the tensile vibrations of -CH2 and -NH3 + [14,43,44]. At the same time, [PW12O40]3− has a strong interaction with 2D-CS3.5-NH2, leading to a slight red shift of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW at 958.09 cm−1, suggesting that the immobilization of HPW was successful. The weight loss of 2D-CS3.5, 2D-CS3.5-NH2, 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW and pure HPW is exhibited in Fig. S4. Two distinct stages of weight loss: free water and bound water are shown in the weight loss curves of HPW. There was a total weight loss of 7.86% from room temperature (RT) to 800°C and a minor weight loss (∼0.61%) from 350 to 500°C. Little weight loss in HPW in the range of 500°C to 800°C suggests that HPW is stable at higher temperatures. Weight loss from room temperature to 100°C is accounted for the evaporation of free water from the 2D-CS3.5 material, while the weight loss in the range of 100°C to 800°C (∼7.85%) is accounted for the loss of its surface hydroxyl groups. Based on the physical and chemical properties of 2D-CS3.5-NH2, the total weight loss was 14.91% from RT to 800°C, while the considerable weight loss between 350 and 550°C (∼6.83%) belonged to the loss of hydroxyl and amino groups. As can be seen from these results, more weight loss was observed for 2D-CS3.5-NH2 than 2D-CS3.5, which was attributed to the decomposition of the amino group of the former at high temperature [45]. In the range of 100–800°C, the 2D channel catalyst showed a weight loss of 14.39%, mostly between 350 and 550°C (∼5.75%), which is in agreement with the weight loss of HPW and 2D-CS3.5-NH2. It can be clearly seen that the weight loss of 2D channel catalyst is less than that of 2D-CS3.5-NH2 and 2D-CS3.5, suggesting that 2D-CS3.5-NH2 has a good immobilization effect on HPW. Further investigation of chemical state of the surface of 2D channel catalyst was carried out using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW consists mainly of W, P, N, Si and O by the measured spectrum (Fig. 4 A). The C 1 s spectrum showed a peak at 284.88 eV and (Fig. 4B), indicating that APTES was successfully grafted onto the 2D-CS3.5. -NH2 peak of APTES appears at 399.59 eV [46,47], while the peak of -NH3 + at 401.63 eV is created by the interaction of amino groups and HPW in the N 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4C) [48]. These results showed that plenty of -NH2 groups were grafted onto the 2D-CS3.5 carrier, some of them interacted with the HPW anion and played a crucial role in dispersing the catalytic active site. In comparison with our previous work [21], after the HPW loading was changed from 20% to 25%, the peak intensity of -NH2 was lower due to the anchoring of more HPW, which better reflects that the -NH2 groups were fully utilized. Furthermore, the 134.29 eV peak in the P 2p spectrum (Fig. 4D) was due to little phosphorus in the HPW. At the same time, it is also observed that the double peaks of 4f5/2 (37.76 eV) and 4f7/2 (35.61 eV) of W 4f (Fig. 4E) can be classified as W6+ [49]. In Fig. 4F, the O 1 s peaks of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW appear at 530.27 eV and 532.47 eV, which corresponds to the Si-O-Si/Si-O-H bond and W-O-W bond, respectively [50]. It was indicated by these findings that the carriers had plenty of hydroxyl groups on its surface, which happened to contribute to the grafted amino groups. Catalytic performance Effect of different types of 2D channel catalysts and HPW content To compare the catalytic performance of 25% 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW with other catalysts, a range of experiments with diverse catalysts were investigated including blank experiments. As shown in Fig. 5 A, by comparing the catalytic performance of HPW with that of HPMo, it was found that the performance of HPW was better than that of HPMo. After being anchored, the catalytic performance of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW (XMO=91.68%, SEMO=90.03%) was significantly better than that of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPMO (XMO=79.14%, SEMO=89.92%). Therefore, HPW was selected as the active component of the catalyst for the epoxidation of MO. (The red line represents the conversion of MO and the blue bar represents the selectivity of EMO) It was found that the performance is related to the particle size [21]. Using different catalyst carriers (Fig. 5B), the performance obtained with 2D-CS3.5 as a catalytic carrier was significantly better than that obtained with other carriers. This result may be due to the fact that 2D-CSx prepared at aqueous ammonia usage of 3.5 mL has a more suitable pore structure for the epoxidation of MO. Compared with the 2D-CS4-NH2-HPW catalyst, the conversion of MO was almost unchanged, but the selectivity of EMO was significantly lower (SEMO=82.59%). This is due to the fact that after the pore size is sufficient, the larger particle size of the carrier is not conducive to the selective generation of EMO. Moreover, the catalytic performance of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW was much better than that of MCM-41-NH2-HPW (XMO=71.65%, SEMO=78.53%, Fig.S5). To investigate the effect of amino-functionalization on the catalytic activity, a series of experiments were investigated (Fig. 5C). Apparently, 25% 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW had the best catalytic performance. When 25% 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW was used for the epoxidation of MO, the conversion of MO could reach 91.68% and the selectivity of EMO was 90.03%. Notably, the catalytic efficiency of 25% 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW was higher than that of 25% 2D-CS3.5-HPW (XMO = 82.16%, SEMO = 75.99%), which was attributed to the amino-modified layered silica that promoted the dispersion of HPW, thus providing more acid active sites. Under the same reaction conditions, if HPW is used directly as the epoxidation catalyst, the selectivity of EMO is only 2.52%, although the conversion of MO can reach 98.45%. This can be attributed to the fact that although the abundance of HPW enhanced double bond oxidation, the strong acidic environment also led to ring opening of the epoxides, making the EMO selectivity lower. Furthermore, the catalytic activity of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW samples with different HPW loading (10–30%) were investigated, keeping the weight of all catalysts constant (100 mg), corresponding results are shown in Fig. 5D. When the HPW content was increased from 10% to 30%, the first conversion of MO increased from 56.79% to 91.68% and then decreased to 68.77%. The selectivity of EMO first increased from 51.96% to 90.03% and then decreased to 62.73%. The result is due to the fact that at low HPW loading, it is not enough to provide the acid active sites for the oxidation of the double bond, and the introduction of excessive HPW leads to the agglomeration and masks the catalytic active center making the catalytic capacity reduced. In addition, the result may also be related to the gradual decrease in the pore volume and specific surface area of the sample (Fig.3A-B and Table 1). Interestingly, the optimal values of the conversion of MO and the selectivity of EMO were obtained when the loading of HPW was 25%. The TOF of different catalysts in the epoxidation reaction of MO was compared, as shown in Fig. S6A and B. In the catalysts prepared with different carriers for the epoxidation of MO (Fig. S6A), it was found that the lowest TOF value (29h−1) was obtained when 2D-CS2.5-NH2-HPW was used, which was due to the fact that the 2D-CS2.5 material had not yet formed good 2D channels, which was not conducive to mass transfer. Thereafter, the TOF of the prepared catalysts gradually increased, and the extreme value of 48 h−1 was achieved when the 2D-CS3.5 material was used as the carrier for the catalysts. However, the TOF started to decrease when the 2D-CS4-NH2-HPW catalyst was used, which was due to the fact that the continuous increase of the particle size was not conducive to the reaction when the pore width was large enough. It was worth noting that the TOF of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW was significantly higher than that of MCM-41-NH2-HPW. This was because 2D-CS3.5 had an excellent 2D channel structure, which was more conducive to the epoxidation reaction of MO. In addition, we also calculated the TOF of the 2D channel catalysts prepared with different loadings of HPW (Fig. S6B). It was found that the TOF first increased and then decreased with increasing HPW loading and achieved an extreme value of 48 h−1 at 25% HPW loading. This was because when the loading content of HPW on 2D-CS3.5-NH2 was low, it could not provide enough active sites. After the extreme value achieved, continuing to increase the HPW loading on 2D-CS3.5-NH2 would lead to agglomeration of HPW particles thus masking the active sites. Therefore, 25% 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW was used as the optimal catalyst for this reaction. Effect of H2O2/C=C molar ratio In order to explore the best reaction conditions, a number of modifications were investigated, including the molar ratio of substrate to oxidant, catalyst dosage, temperature, and time. A study was conducted to investigate the effect of H2O2/C=C molar ratio (1 to 4) for MO epoxidation (Fig. 6 A). Obviously, the conversion of MO increased from 47.57% at a molar ratio of 1 to 97.62% at a molar ratio of 4 by increasing the amount of oxidant, indicating that a higher H2O2/C=C molar ratio favors the conversion of MO. However, at a molar ratio of 4, although the conversion of MO was high, the selectivity of the epoxide was low at 44.59%, which was most likely due to the decrease in selectivity caused by the decomposition of excess H2O2 to produce water and the ring-opening reaction of EMO in an acidic environment. Therefore, the optimal molar ratio of H2O2/C=C for this reaction condition is 3. Under this condition, the conversion of MO was 91.68%, the selectivity of EMO was 90.03%, and the final yield of EMO was 82.54%. In addition, the conversion rate of hydrogen peroxide was determined to be 92.15% by iodine value [38], indicating that hydrogen peroxide was fully utilized. At a small H2O2/C=C molar ratio, the concentration of hydrogen peroxide is low enough to oxidize the carbon-carbon double bond by forming peroxyphosphotungstic acid, resulting in a low yield of epoxide. Even though equal amounts of H2O2 peroxide and C=C of MO are theoretically required to carry out the reaction, a slight excess of H2O2 is required because H2O2 decomposes into H2O and O2, which is not avoidable in catalytic systems. Effect of catalyst amount The impact of catalyst mass in the range of 10 to 150 mg was investigated (Fig. 6B). Through increasing the amount of catalyst, the conversion of MO increased from 36.37% at 10 mg to 99.20% at 150 mg, essentially achieving complete conversion. However, the selectivity of EMO increased from 61.26% at 10 mg to 90.03% at 100 mg, and decreased to 43.75% when the weight of catalyst was continued to increase to 150 mg. This is mainly due to side reactions such as ring opening of EMO at high concentrations of acidic environment when using a large amount of catalyst, and also possibly due to the hindrance of mass transfer by the addition of excess catalyst. Therefore, the optimal amount of catalyst to be used is 100 mg. Effect of reaction temperature and time For the purpose of confirming the thermodynamic effect of MO epoxidation, this reaction was investigated at diverse temperature (Fig. 6C). The best values of the epoxidation reaction conversion and selectivity were obtained at 90°C with 91.68% and 90.03%, respectively. As the reaction temperature increased, the conversion of MO increased, while the selectivity of EMO started to decrease. The epoxidation reaction of MO was previously reported to be limited by the mass transfer process, and higher temperatures could improve the conversion rate [51]. Thus, conversion of MO increased from 67.08% at 70°C to 96.57% at 100°C when the temperature was increased from 70°C to 100°C. However, when increasing the temperature to 100°C, the selectivity of EMO was only 39.94%, so continuously increasing the temperature is not a wise choice. In addition, there was a significant increase in the conversion of MO with time (Fig. 6D), suggesting that the epoxidation of MO could be effectively catalyzed using 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW. It was found that the optimal duration of the epoxidation reaction under this condition was 4 h, and the conversion of MO and the selectivity of EMO were 91.68% and 90.03%, respectively. A shorter reaction time is insufficient to generate EMO, while the long-term presence of epoxides in acidic environment can lead to its ring-opening reaction and reduce epoxide selectivity. In summary, the optimal temperature and optimal time for this reaction are 90°C and 4 h, respectively. Recyclability of catalyst Reusability and stability of 2D channel catalysts were identified as two critical factors for their practical applications. Therefore, we performed cyclic experiments to study the stability of 2D channel catalyst in the MO epoxidation reaction. The catalysts were separated by centrifugation, washed repeatedly with anhydrous ethanol and dried at 80°C before being used in the next experiment. Catalytic efficiency of the recovered 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW was investigated under optimal experimental conditions. For the prepared catalysts, they exhibited outstanding cycling performance as shown in Fig. 7 A. After five cycles, the conversion of MO could still reach 88.27% and the selectivity of EMO remained at 87.97%. The result was attributed to the robustness of the prepared layered silica carrier itself and the amino-modified layered silica firmly anchored the HPW particles, which allowed the catalyst to maintain good catalytic performance. Upon completion of the fifth cycle, the 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst was recovered, then washed and dried for characterization. As shown in Fig. 7B, the XRD pattern of the recovered catalyst was found to be almost indistinguishable from that of the fresh 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst, indicating its structural stability and good reusability. The SEM confirmed that the catalyst still has an axially stacked laminar structure (Fig. 7C). Taken together, it showed that the catalyst had good structural stability and reusability. Based on ICP analysis (Table S1), ICP testing was conducted on the catalyst used 5 times, and it was found that the HPW content was 22.51 wt %, indicating that the HPW was still well anchored on 2D-CS3.5 without significant leaching. Catalytic mechanism A rigorous study of the catalytic mechanism of 2D channel catalysts on MO epoxidation was carried out. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry was performed to monitor the catalytic epoxidation process of MO. As expected, after 4 h of reaction, EMO was detected in the organic phase, indicating that the 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst achieved conversion of MO and successful synthesis of the target product. Meanwhile, the characteristic signal of hydroxyl radical (•OH) was detected by EPR test in the absence of MO, as shown in Fig. 8 . The result shows that the produced peroxy phosphotungstic acid is unstable, and peroxy phosphotungstic acid decomposes and releases •OH. With the increase of time, more and more peroxy phosphotungstic acid is generated, and correspondingly more •OH is released. On the basis of above discussion and analysis, it was shown in Scheme 1 that the mechanism of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyzed MO epoxidation. The accessible open transport 2D channel of the 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst permits more MO molecules to diffuse arbitrarily from the 2D channel to the interior of the catalyst, which offers a variety of chances for access to the catalytic active sites. In Keggin HPW/H2O2 system, H2O2 reacts with HPW to produce highly active peroxy phosphotungstic acid which plays a leading role in the epoxidation of MO. Subsequently, peroxy phosphotungstic acid is decomposed into phosphotungstic acid due to instability, realizing that the catalyst continuously participates in the reaction [52]. Meanwhile, a small amount of EMO undergoes epoxy ring opening reaction to generate by-products such as 9,10-dihydroxystearic acid methyl ester. These findings suggest that the unique accessible open transport channel structure of 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW can promote the diffusion of reactants and enhance the production of epoxy products. Compared to the other catalysts published, 2D channel catalysts showed the most remarkable performance for the epoxidation of MO in a similar catalytic system (Table 2 ). The conversion of MO reached an impressive 91.68% and the selectivity of EMO reached 90.03% at 4 h. This is much faster than previously reported epoxidation catalysts. The result again reflects the fact that the prepared catalysts have accessible open channels and MO fully contacted the active sites present inside and outside the carrier. Conclusion In conclusion, a series of 2D channel silica loaded HPA were successfully designed to achieve rapid and efficient epoxidation of MO. Among them, 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW showed superior catalytic activity when comparing catalysts with HPMO and HPW as active components. 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst displayed axially stacked layered structures and high specific surface areas, which facilitated the dispersion and molecular diffusion of active components. As a result of these unique characteristics, MO can penetrate arbitrarily from the open 2D transport channels to the catalyst interior to generate the target epoxide. 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW catalyst exhibited high catalytic efficiency in the epoxidation reaction of MO, with 91.68% conversion and 90.03% selectivity, respectively. The excellent epoxidation activity of 2D channel silica catalyst was due to its unique and available open transport channels, which facilitated the exchange and diffusion of reactants. More notably, the prepared catalyst exhibited favorable reusability, and maintained its catalytic activity after five uses, making it a promising material for industrial epoxidation and meeting sustainable development strategies. coredata.dc:description: For the epoxidation of methyl oleate (MO), slow chemical reaction rate resulted from poor mass transfer remains a tough problem. Herein, we demonstrate a series of efficient 2D channel catalysts with accessible open transport channels, which provides an idea strategy for boosting epoxidation of MO and shortening its reaction time. 2D channel catalysts (2D-CSx-NH2-HPA) are fabricated by immobilizing heteropoly acid (HPA) on aminopropyl-functionalized 2D channel silica (2D-CSx-NH2), in which HPA is highly dispersed. These catalysts are applied to the epoxidation of MO, and the results show that the epoxidation performance of 2D channel catalysts for MO is related to its particle size and HPA types. As expected, the 2D-CS3.5-NH2-HPW with a length of 300 nm and an equatorial diameter of 150 nm exhibits outstanding catalytic activity (XMO = 91.68%) and epoxide selectivity (SEMO = 90.03%) with only 4 hours, which is much faster than that of majority of epoxidation catalysts reported so far. The excellent catalytic activity of 2D channel catalyst benefits from the appropriate pore width and particle size, which play an important role in exchanging substrates and dispersing active components. This study uses 2D channel catalyst to effectively shorten the reaction time of MO epoxidation, which paves a new avenue to develop other 2D channel materials for novel catalytic applications.
coredata.dc:title: Constructing 2D channel catalysts with accessible open transport channels for boosting epoxidation of methyl oleate
